Film of the day

  • JOSEP

    Aurel France, 2020

    FROM FRANCE WITH LOVE

    Josep is an insightful portrayal of Catalan artist Josep Bartolí, focusing on his escape from Franco’s regime. Directed by award-winning cartoonist Aurel, whose minimalist and evocative animation matches Bartolí’s own style, this is a stunning and poetic meditation on resistance, memory, and art.

    More info

  • NOCTURNO 29

    Pere Portabella Spain, 1968

    FIRST FILMS FIRST

    Starkly shot in black-and-white, Nocturno 29 is the moody debut from renaissance man Pere Portabella (experimental filmmaker, senator, intellectual and producer of Buñuel’s Viridiana!). His fragmentary ’68 masterpiece stars Lucia Bosé and was co-scripted by the great poet Joan Brossa.

    More info

  • SPRING BREAKERS

    Harmony Korine United States, 2012

    Another raucous, rowdy work from Harmony Korine, this entrancingly voyeuristic look at girls gone wild is as overwhelming as it is overstimulating. In your face, ingeniously iconoclastic, and shocking from start to finish, Spring Breakers stars an unrecognizable and excellent James Franco.

    More info

  • A FAMILY TOUR

    Ying Liang Taiwan, 2018

    Exclusive

    A poignant look at the inseparability of the political and personal, director Ying Liang draws on his own experiences of asylum to tell this valiant story about an exiled film director. Above all, A Family Tour is a stunningly beautiful work on the bonds of family, identity, and the urge to belong.

    More info

  • ORPHEUS

    Jean Cocteau France, 1950

    FROM FRANCE WITH LOVE

    The middle film in Jean Cocteau’s delirious Orphic Trilogy sees the great artist transposing the famous Greek myth onto the beatnik world of Left Bank Paris. A shimmering dream world unfolds from a mirrored portal: a rich parable on self-obsession that can be enjoyed here in a stunning restoration.

    More info

  • SHAME

    Steve McQueen United Kingdom, 2011

    Carried by an extraordinary Michael Fassbender, Shame is a haunting, ferocious drama from one of the most unflinching directors working today. One of 2011’s best, it was a lightning rod of discussion from the moment it premiered at Venice, where it won the Critics’ Prize and Best Actor.

    More info

  • ABOUT SOME MEANINGLESS EVENTS

    Mostafa Derkaoui Morocco, 1974

    A MUBI Release
    REDISCOVERED

    Should cinema entertain? Should it tackle social struggle? Crucial questions are raised in Mostafa Derkaoui’s engrossing, revelatory meta-investigation, banned upon release and tragically lost for 45 years. Now gloriously restored, this unknown yet essential masterwork can finally meet its audience.

    More info

  • HEROES DON'T DIE

    Aude-Léa Rapin France, 2019

    FROM FRANCE WITH LOVE

    Combining elements of the ghost story and travelogue, Aude Léa Rapin casts Adèle Haenel as her stand-in in this, her formally daring (and metafictional!) feature debut. Heroes Don’t Die is truly unpredictable: a high-concept reflection on the Bosnian War and a film totally unbound from convention.

    More info

  • MIA MADRE

    Nanni Moretti Italy, 2015

    NANNI MORETTI: A TRIPLE
    BILL

    Working slightly outside of his usual autobiographical mode, Nanni Moretti (The Son’s Room) still draws on personal experience for Mia Madre. A scene-stealing John Turturro stars in this tragicomic story about love, death, and filmmaking—with a soundtrack featuring Arvo Pärt and Jarvis Cocker!

    More info

  • THE CAIMAN

    Nanni Moretti Italy, 2006

    NANNI MORETTI: A TRIPLE
    BILL

    Director Nanni Moretti is both a cinephile who eagerly comments on the state of cinema, and a virulent detractor of Silvio Berlusconi’s politics. These two facets dizzyingly merge with The Caiman, a self-reflective and mischievous comedy about the making of a satirical comedy about the Caiman…

    More info

  • WE HAVE A POPE

    Nanni Moretti Italy, 2011

    NANNI MORETTI: A TRIPLE
    BILL

    Can Palme d’Or-winner Nanni Moretti see the future? As if predicting Pope Benedict XVI’s surprise resignation, with customary wit and warmth the Italian auteur directed this droll, sensitive comedy about an individual (the legendary actor Michel Piccoli) and an institution thrown into confusion.

    More info

  • BETTY BLUE

    Jean-Jacques Beineix France, 1986

    Jean-Jacques Beineix’s stylish, ultra-erotic film—with an unforgettably fierce debut by Béatrice Dalle—erupted with such a slick new style that a whole movement was named around it (along with the work of Luc Besson & Leos Carax!): Cinéma du look. Shown here in its revitalized director’s cut form.

    More info

  • MID90S

    Jonah Hill United States, 2018

    Exclusive

    More than a decade after his iconic performance in Superbad, Jonah Hill moves behind the camera with this ode to friendship as the source of true solace. Nostalgia permeates the celluloid texture of this exhilarating, heart-warming coming-of-age film that tenderly reclaims male vulnerability.

    More info

  • HOLIDAY

    Isabella Eklöf Denmark, 2018

    Exclusive
    DEBUTS

    Be warned: this is no placid summer’s tale! Isabella Eklöf’s sun-drenched debut is as intoxicating as it is brutal. An unflinching study of female oppression whose perspective on abuse has stirred up controversy, Holiday is daring filmmaking that exudes confidence while asking crucial questions.

    More info

  • THE MUSEUM OF IMAGINATION

    Amit Dutta India, 2012

    THE INIMITABLE IMAGE:
    AN AMIT DUTTA RETROSPECTIVE

    An inventive mapping of art historian Dr. B N Goswamy’s life and his work on Pahari paintings, The Museum of Imagination generates a mesmerising visual account of how creations outlast their creators. This film subtly sheds light on Amit Dutta’s own ingenious exploration of Pahari artist Nainsukh.

    More info

  • LIFE IS A MIRACLE

    Emir Kusturica Serbia, 2004

    Probably breaking all of the safety rules that ever existed, Emir Kusturica’s Life Is a Miracle is a zany and surrealist vignette of Yugoslavia on the brink of the Bosnian War. A cacophonous, swirling and drunken celebration, with tinges of tragedy and criticism surrounding the conflict.

    More info

  • UN FILM DRAMATIQUE

    Eric Baudelaire France, 2019

    A MUBI Release
    VIEWFINDER

    In a beautiful act of collective creation, Eric Baudelaire shares the director’s chair with twenty schoolchildren in Un film dramatique. The result? A kaleidoscope of spontaneous self-representation, an ode to both subjectivity and collaboration movingly exploring the possibilities of cinema.

    More info

  • HAM ON RYE

    Tyler Taormina United States, 2019

    A MUBI Release
    DEBUTS

    A wonderful cast of suburban teens face a rite of passage—fraught with anxiety and desire—that starts in the world of Richard Linklater and ends in that of David Lynch. Tyler Taormina’s sly but surprisingly touching debut plays with and then upends the clichés of American end-of-school comedies.

    More info

  • ALL OF A SUDDEN

    Asli Özge Germany, 2016

    Turkey-born, Germany-based director Asli Özge’s confident drama-thriller doesn’t shy away from urgent ideas, while also retaining an engaging story. Elegantly shot, the film asks how one bad public moment can alter someone’s life, slowly revealing the brutality of society towards its own members.

    More info

  • PICKPOCKET

    Jia Zhangke China, 1998

    FIRST FILMS FIRST

    Exploring the pervasive, entrenched connection between crime & capitalism throughout society, Pickpocket hails from A Touch of Sin and Ash is Purest White director Jia Zhangke, who has gone on to become one of the greatest chroniclers of his country. An accomplished debut from a modern master.

    More info

  • GOOD NIGHT, AND GOOD LUCK.

    George Clooney United States, 2005

    George Clooney directed this thrilling drama about the fearful early days of television, when these new journalists had to define their purpose and integrity – more relevant than ever in the age of “phone-hacking”. This award-winning film, with a brilliant cast, reveals a crucial moment in history.

    More info

  • SANTA SANGRE

    Alejandro Jodorowsky Mexico, 1989

    THE PSYCHOMAGIC CINEMA
    OF ALEJANDRO JODOROWSKY

    Cult auteur Alejandro Jodorowsky turned up at the Cannes film festival in 1989 with something refreshingly new: a psychedelic, psychological, and time-shifting horror story. Santa Sangre explores the extreme (yes: perverse) ties between a boy and his mother with macabre, Fellini-esque verve.

    More info

  • AUGUST 32ND ON EARTH

    Denis Villeneuve Canada, 1998

    FIRST FILMS FIRST

    Prior to making some of the biggest sci-fi blockbusters of the 21st century, Denis Villeneuve directed this French New Wave-influenced drama. Premiering at Cannes, August 32nd on Earth highlights the striking visuals that would become Villeneuve’s trademark, here presented in a gorgeous restoration.

    More info

  • MY SISTER'S GOOD FORTUNE

    Angela Schanelec Germany, 1995

    FIRST FILMS FIRST

    With her I Was at Home, But… helmed as one of last year’s best arthouse movies, we look back at German auteur Angela Schanelec’s first leap into feature filmmaking. An unusual take on desire and its ambiguous nature, this ethereal drama is filled with powerful, skilfully-crafted observation.

    More info

  • THE SMALL TOWN

    Nuri Bilge Ceylan Turkey, 1997

    FIRST FILMS FIRST

    This stunning exploration of the life of a rural family marks Nuri Bilge Ceylan’s highly personal debut feature. Shot in poignant black-and-white cinematography, and starring members of his own family, The Small Town is a low-budget, minimalist ode to the slow rhythms of life in the countryside.

    More info

  • LOVE

    Gaspar Noé France, 2015

    We can always rely on enfant terrible Gaspar Noé to raise eyebrows: more than a decade after Irréversible, Noé again goes for the jugular with Love, a fittingly tongue-in-cheek title for this fascinating ménage-a-trois unsimulated sex drama.

    More info

  • THE BASILISKS

    Lina Wertmüller Italy, 1963

    FIRST FILMS FIRST

    A socialist trailblazer, Lina Wertmüller began her career as assistant to Fellini, whose influence permeates her neorealist debut. Scored by Ennio Morricone and shot by the DP of 8½ , this mesmerizing drama delves into the trials of small-town Italian life. Bask in the glory of this new restoration.

    More info

  • WATCHTOWER

    Pelin Esmer Turkey, 2012

    SPOTLIGHT ON PELIN ESMER

    Pelin Esmer’s third film (yet her first work of pure fiction) movingly looks at the hidden tragedies that ordinary people face in their lives. In this meditative melodrama about an incongruous couple overcoming their trauma, Esmer patiently explores the emotions of individuals isolated from society.

    More info

  • HAPPY AS LAZZARO

    Alice Rohrwacher Italy, 2018

    Exclusive

    If The Wonders impressed for her gentle touch as a storyteller, Alice Rohrwacher’s sublime latest feature confirmed her as one of today’s most promising auteurs. Re-inventing the tropes of magical realism for the modern age, Happy as Lazzaro is a timeless journey into the essence of rural life.

    More info

  • MILLION DOLLAR BABY

    Clint Eastwood United States, 2004

    Winner of four Academy Awards, this deeply heartfelt and tender masterpiece is one of Clint Eastwood’s finest films. Starring Hilary Swank, Morgan Freeman, and Eastwood himself, the three bring profound emotion and vulnerability to a story of loss and regret that goes in unexpected directions.

    More info
